variant.question: With regard to the CG and its effect on performance select the correct statement.

options.text: A forward CG increases stability and increases fuel consumption.
An aft CG increases stability and decreases fuel consumption.
A forward CG increases stability and decreases fuel consumption.
An aft CG decreases stability and increases fuel consumption

variant.question: CS-23 and CS-25 use the term "net take-off flight path" to describe certain performance elements. The "net take-off flight path" is the...

options.text: actual flight path of the aeroplane reduced by a safety margin.
flight path of the aeroplane with NO safety margins applied.
the flight path gradient corrected for non-ISA conditions.
increased flight path gradient to provide a safety margin on the flight test data

variant.question: Which statement regarding gross performance is true?

options.text: Calculated flight performance without a safety factor.
Calculated flight performance with a safety factor.
Actual flight performance with a safety factor.
Actual flight performance without a safety factor.
Less than 9 passenger seats, MCTOM less than 5.7 t, propellers
More than 9 passenger seats, MCTOM greater than 5.7 t, turbine engines
More than 9 passenger seats, MCTOM greater than 5.7 t propellers­­
Less than 9 passenger seats, MCTOM less than 5.7 t, turbine engines
The average performance which a fleet of aeroplanes should achieve if satisfactorily maintained and flown in accordance with the techniques described in the manual
65 percent of net performance
The maximum performance which a fleet of aeroplanes should achieve if satisfactorily maintained and flown in accordance with the techniques described in the manual
The minimum performance which a fleet of aeroplanes should achieve if satisfactorily maintained and flown in accordance with the techniques described in the manual

variant.question: Compare the take-off performance for the same aircraft with the same mass at airport A (elevation 10 feet AMSL) with take-off performance at airport B (elevation 5 330 feet AMSL). Assume the same temperature at both airports. At airport B, the take-off distance will be (1) _____ and the climb gradient will be (2) _____.

options.text: (1) longer; (2) reduced.
(1) shorter; (2) increased.
(1) longer; (2) increased.
(1) shorter; (2) reduced.

variant.question: Which of the following statements about performance definitions and safety factors is correct?

options.text: The net climb gradient is the gross climb gradient minus a safety margin.
The gross take-off flight path must clear all obstacles by at least 35 ft.
The net and gross climb gradients are equal for a four engine aircraft.
The gross climb gradient is the net climb gradient minus a safety margin.

variant.question: Which of the following statements about performance definitions and safety factors is correct?

options.text: The net climb gradient is the gross climb gradient minus a safety margin.
The gross climb gradient is the net climb gradient minus a safety margin.
The net and gross climb gradients are equal for a four-engined aeroplane.
The gross take-off flight path must clear all obstacles by at least 35 ft.

variant.question: Which of the following statements about performance definitions and safety factors is correct?

options.text: The net climb gradient is the gross climb gradient minus a safety margin.
The gross take off flight path must clear all obstacles by at least 35 ft.
The gross climb gradient is the net climb gradient minus a safety margin.
The net and gross climb gradients are equal for a four-engined aeroplane.

variant.question: The net flight path climb gradient after take-off compared to the gross climb gradient is

options.text: smaller.
equal.
depends on type of aircraft.
larger.

variant.question: The diminishment to be applied to the gross gradient (take-off climb) to obtain the net gradient for a twin-engined Class A aeroplane is
Above what height must the aircraft have a positive climb gradient, during the "en-route phase of the net flight path”?

options.text: 500 ft

variant.question: During the "en-route phase of the net flight path" above what height must you have a positive climb gradient?

options.text: B. 500 ft

variant.question:
A turn has to be initiated in the second segment of the take-off flight path, where a net climb gradient of 2.0 % is required due to an obstacle. The bank angle of the twin-engine jet during the turn is 15° but the AFM gives a decrement of 0.5 % for the turn.
What is the minimum required gross gradient before commencing the turn, if regulation and obstacle clearance must be considered?
During the initial climb out you are required to do a 15° turn to the left to avoid an obstacle. What will happen to the total drag and the climb gradient? The total drag will ...

options.text: increase and the climb gradient will decrease.
decrease and the climb gradient will decrease.
decrease and the climb gradient will increase.
increase and the climb gradient will increase.

variant.question:
A two engine turbojet has to initiate a turn in the second segment of the take-off flight path. During the turn there is an obstacle that requires a net climb gradient of 2.0% in order to clear the obstacle. The bank angle during the turn is 15° and the flight manual gives a decrement for the turn of 0.5%.

Taking into account both the regulation and obstacle clearance, what will be the minimum gross gradient required before commencing the turn?

A two-engine turbojet has to initiate a turn in the second segment of the take-off flight path. During the turn there is an obstacle that requires a net climb gradient of 2.0 % in order to clear the obstacle. The bank angle during the turn is 15° and the flight manual gives a decrement for the turn of 0.5 %. Taking into account both the regulation and obstacle clearance, what will be the minimum gross gradient required before commencing the turn?

During the turn there is an obstacle that requires a net climb gradient of 2.0% in order to clear the obstacle. The bank angle during the turn is 15° and the flight manual gives a decrement for the turn of 0.5%. 

Taking into account both the regulation and obstacle clearance, what will be the minimum gross gradient required before commencing the turn?
